content: After solving it I see there are successful submissions from people that just ignore the offset and always use seed 0 and still find a match. I feel there should be test cases where this approach should not work. It seems you picked the seeds of all test-cases to have the same low byte as one of the 17-cycle values of seed 0... Bad test case variety.

Great puzzle, loved it. Two things though :
- java default reading is incorrect,  input "offset" should be readLong()
- input "offset" is actually not needed to solve the puzzle, and that way it's genuinely encryption breaking. How would the rebels know about the offset ?

I've swapped the last two paragraphs of the list of "figured out" things because separating the one about "undiscarded numbers" from the part about which are discarded and which aren't (hint: it's more of a truncation than a sieve) made it a bit confusing.

I've approved because the following doesn't really hinder solving.

But I'm STILL uneasy about the 64-bit offset. With such an offset, the Empire can't encode its own messages. So of course it already "cheats" to actually encode, so of course it knows the cypher is weak.

In my opinion, this puzzle has to be classified as either Hard or Very Hard. The challenges have been described by sammck and PaulH in their comments. And if you have read the author's solution code, you will find even more ideas which a player may not easily come up with.

I have revised the puzzle statement taking into account sammck's and PaulH's comments.

I agree with everything Sam says below, the challenge is figuring out that the large number spaces don't need to be searched.  Also as he said, the statement that the message is XORed with a stream of random numbers is technically incorrect, it's xored with the bottom 8 bits of the random number.

As this is a well know way of breaking simple cyphers, I think it's an interesting problem, but for me I'd prefer making it clear that the problem breaks down to 7140 keys to check, and also making clear which possible characters "The Empire" can use in its messages.  I checked valid for ascii >= 32 <=126 but, I think the puzzle would be better if the characters used were made clear in the description (or even perhaps limiting  them to uppercase/lowercase/numbers and a single punctuation mark (.))

I had fun and it took about 10 min in python to solve all the test cases.

This problem was not actually very hard once you recognize that there are effectively only 7140 different seeds since the modulo operator throws away all the other information when feeding forward to the next random number.

Given that, it is easy to try all 7140 possible seeds, select those that work for '@', and then ensure that if there is more than one unique answer, all the remaining characters decode to printable ASCII (32-126). It is still possible to have collisions but it did not happen in any of the test cases.

One thing that did not seem clear from your instructions: For encryption, in addition to XOR'ing the random number (in the range 0-7139) with the plaintext ascii code (in the range 0-255), you are truncating the result to 8 bits (0-255). That is not at all implicit and should be explained in the description.

I'd say this is medium difficulty since the only tricky thing is realizing that throwing away the residual bits when feeding forward the previous random number means that the random number sequence must repeat every 7140 times (or less) and there are effectively only 7140 possible seeds.
The new "Difficulty" feature is online. I guess you should change your puzzle difficulty to "Hard" or "Very Hard"
Just for my ego, has anyone tried to solve this? I would love to hear your comments.
Why is there a "@"? Is it useful?
I can see a downvote. Can you also provide some feedback? I'd like to improve it or, at least, understand why a puzzle like this is not appropriate.

Yes. Without the '@' it cannot be solved.
The point of the puzzle is to find the weakness of the Empire cryptographic method.  I thought it was good way to stimulate a reflection on how secure an encryption method can be.
I choose the messages all starting with the same information as a weakness, because it was one of the the flaws of the famous Enigma Machine.
I was hoping it was an interesting puzzle but it does not seems to be the case :)
BTW, This method is close to the way GSM phone communication are encrypted.

I'm uneasy with the offset<2^63 part.

This effectively rules out even verifying cyphers.

Maybe some spy computer scientist is involved and cheats the Empire into believing and using this encoding approach and having a sense of (false) security. Not everyone in the Empire is that tech-savvy, I guess...

And yup, the encoding process may not be what actually happens. I've edited "You figured out" to become "The rebellion figured out" to shift the burden to them for their inaccurate finding :P
There are some interesting seeds that don't have a cycle length of 17, but lower instead, even one with length 1. Some test-cases for them might be interesting as well.

Because of the small number of possible effective seeds and short cycle time, even without the known plaintext '@', it's possible to quickly attempt all possible decoded sequences, and filter them to those that contain only printable ascii. The number of results for a given cipher text will be small, and can be quickly scanned for sensible text.
